messageBody:
Greetings,
This is true. I recall reading about that 'trap', and I can
definitely agree that's where the breakdown is. For my
project, there are (imo) very well-defined, good reasons
to test like this. (A small one of which is that it was the
perfect way to build the server structure in a 'test-first'
manner, a much larger one is knowing the precise
performance implications of each functional unit of the
program.) They have nothing to do with JUnit's mission,
however, and everything to do with mine as a developer.

And you hit the nail on the head as well, when noting the
functional vs. unit aspect of it. I have a small set of tests
that test the overall correctness, and then the larger
functional tests that *call* the smaller tests, in order to
reuse test knowledge. (Don't Repeat Yourself.)

I am trying to do both with JUnit, under the theory that whenever
I make a change, I re-run the test suite and if it works, then I'm
comfortable that I'm not going to have to deal with QA, because
my test suite is sufficiently complete and similar to actual
application use that (barring infrastructure issues) my code will
Just Work.

So the answer is that what I'm trying to do is beyond the scope
of JUnit. A small mod to JUnit would let me do it, but that mod
wouldn't ever be accepted into JUnit-proper because it's effectively
scope creep.

This actually makes me feel a lot better about making a local mod
to JUnit. I normally hate to do something like that without feeding
the patch back, but my project needs are just different than the
target for the JUnit project. I need tests, and I have them, but I
also need the performance numbers that I get, as well as higher
level functional tests, as well as 'behavior under load' tests. You
can't do that with the basic JUnit framework. It's absurd to claim
I *shouldn't* do the other tests, as more tests are good, but I'll
easily agree that it's clearly not what JUnit was designed for.

Thankfully small changes to JUnit make this completely possible
inside its framework, and since it's not under active development,
I don't have to worry about rolling in new versions.

There really are no other well-supported (by tools, at least)
testing frameworks out there, so if I want to do the kind of
testing I *need* to do, my choices are to build an entirely
new framework (which then won't integrate with other
programs like IntelliJ), or extend the quality work already
done.

-- Morgan Schweers

--- In junit@yahoogroups.com, "Ilja Preuss" <preuss@d...> wrote:
> cypherfox wrote:
> > Greetings,
> > I asked about a few feature enhancements, or more accurately
> > if anyone had any reasons they shouldn't be done, or what
> > testing paradigm I might be missing that made them wrong...
>
> Well, the paradigm that Junit follows and with which you seem to
have
> problems is that a testcase should be a full standalone test
scenario
> and shouldn't depend at the results of other testcases at all.
>
> It might be that you are fallen into the "a test method should test
a
> single method call" trap (it shouldn't, it should test a single,
simple
> test scenario); or perhaps your tests are too big and more on the
> functional side than the unit side to be handled effectively using
> Junit.
>
> What do you think?
>
> Cheers, Ilja
